Award.AwardTitle: RET in Engineering and Computer Science Site: National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network RET Program

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a 3 year standard award to support a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering Site program at Georgia Institute of Technology (GA Tech) entitled, "RET Site: National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network (NNIN)", under the direction of Dr. Nancy Healy.

This Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering Site is a renewal of a successful RET Site program hosted by the National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network (NNIN) with the lead at Georgia Institute of Technology and partners at Arizona State University, University of California Santa Barbara, and the University of Minnesota. This site will provide a total of 48 (16 per year for 3 years), in-service, grades 6-12 science teachers and community college faculty within commuting distance of the NNIN university site, an opportunity to engage in high-quality, nanoscale science and engineering (NSE) hands-on research in state-of-the-art nanotechnology facilities at NNIN sites for 7 weeks during the summer with 1 week of follow-up activities throughout the year, and present their research experience at an annual NNIN Professional Development Workshop. The objectives of the program are to actively engage underrepresented science teachers and community college faculty, or those who serve underrepresented students, in NSE research, build a library of NSE classroom activities and broadly disseminate these activities, and develop a long-term support community of professors, graduate students, NNIN staff, science teachers and community college faculty who will advocate STEM and NSE education and career pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoscale science and engineering (NSE) is a fast-growing and interdisciplinary field with wide-ranging applications in engineering, biology, chemistry, physics, and medicine. At a basic level, NSE has significant overlap with standard secondary science curricula making it an excellent vehicle for affecting the STEM pipeline. NSE has great societal and economic potential, with an estimate of 2 million workers needed worldwide by 2018. To address the growing need for a trained and educated workforce, we provided participants with high quality research projects and introduced them to the breadth of NSE possibilities in order motivate their students towards STEM and NSE as a career. The National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network's (NNIN) RET program received its third award from NSF in June 2012. A No Cost Extension was received which extended the award until May 31, 2016.  The goal of this program was to provide hands-on research experiences in nanoscale science and engineering (NSE) for secondary science teachers and community college faculty.  Four universities partnered to receive funding for this RET program: Georgia Tech (lead), Arizona State University, University of California Santa Barbara, and University of Minnesota. The program supported four participants at each site each year for eight weeks: seven weeks of research and design of a teaching module and one week of follow up during the academic year.  Each year one of the sites hosted the NNIN RET Professional Development Workshop for secondary and post-secondary educators.  The purpose of the workshop was for the RETs to present their lessons to other educators as well as network with RETs from the four sites.

 

The objectives of the program were to: 1. actively engage underrepresented science teachers/community college faculty (CCF) -or those that serve underrepresented students-in NSE research; 2. build a library of NSE classroom activities and broadly disseminate these activities; 3. develop a long-term support community of professors,  graduate students, NNIN staff, CCF, and science teachers who will advocate STEM and NSE education and career pathways.  All three objectives were achieved under this award.  This award has supported 62 participants: 34 female (55%); 28 male (45%) and 16 underrepresented minorities (26%).  Approximately two-thirds of the RETs taught in schools that had a large portion of underrepresented students (race, ethnicity, socio-economic). Over the nine years of funding, the lessons developed by the RETs has provided approximately 100 teaching modules that are accessible to anyone at our website: http://nnin.org/education-training/k-12-teachers/nanotechnology-curriculum-materials. This searchable database of lessons has been created for teachers by teachers and tested in classrooms. Survey and focus group results indicate that the participants have presented NSE topics in their teaching, shared their experience with their colleagues, maintained contact with their university researchers as well as the RET support staff, and consider the experience a very positive one that impacted their teaching and career development.  These RETs have shared their experience with their students and are using it to encourage STEM and NSE career pathways.
